children.subject: If you enjoyed CS 61C, I recommend EECS 151. It has a huge (and I mean HUGE) project at the end, but the skills you come out with are highly employable.

As a side note, I'll mention that 120 is basically expected knowledge for any electrical engineer. Like 170 is a "pseudo-requirement" for CS, 120 pops up everywhere in EE. I took 105, 140, and 151 without it and I managed fine because I enjoy circuits a lot, but 120 would have really helped, especially in 140.
+1 on 120 - pretty ubiquitous to just about any subfield of EE.

151 is the most "employable" lab class, so +1 to that. 105 is good to take as well if you want to do circuit design, with 140 being necessary afterward if you want to do analog circuit design. CS 152 is a good follow-on to 151 if you end up enjoying it, and is pretty "employable" in and of itself (151 and 152 will set you up very nicely to become a computer architect).

history.content:
As mentioned in the discussions below, 151 will teach you the skills to become a digital designer (through an incredible amount of work).  105+140 will allow you to get an analog product or test engineer job; if you understand 140 well, you can get a designer position (though it will be admittedly difficult without prior experience as an intern or researcher).  113 after 105 offers the chance to become a power engineer.  

But a word on 120: you don't have to like the subject, but you must know at least the basics- for every job in electrical engineering.  For instance as a product or test engineer, you may be asked (on the job or in an interview) to test the spectral purity of an ADC/DAC- if you don't know what coherent sampling is (or at least what Nyquist's sampling theorem is), you will not get the job.  Obviously you cannot design an ADC/DAC in the first place without that knowledge either.  Even for a digital designer, one of the biggest applications out there is in implementing digital signal processing algorithms.  120 will also open the door to take 123 (DSP), which will open many doors as well (its project is also a lot of work, though not as much as 151).  I don't want to sound too harsh (I understand the feeling, I personally don't enjoy signal processing and had put off 120 as long as I could, I'm a circuits person), but the reality is 120 is a must, and in your case it should be taken right away.  Apart from that you have options- hopefully you find something rewarding, good luck!

I think I am going into my last year, and I am thinking of taking two UD EE classes. While I want recruitable classes, I do not want to take overly theoretical classes like EE120. I would prefer a class with labs. Do any classes come to mind? I have only taken EE16A/B, so classes with no requirements are highly welcome.
history.subject: Recruitable EE classes with labs
